Fields.DialogueText: You look happy, Nenohi. Is acting as our communication hub really as much fun as you make it look?
Sō sō! Even more so, Kanchou! I get to spend as much time as I want talking to interesting people. You wouldn't believe how much I'm learning.
For instance, the English have tea that is very much like Chinese tea! They say that they make it better, but I cannot tell.
And did you know that the Russians make a drink of potatoes? A drink of roots! So silly!

Fields.MenuText: As long as you're happy, so am I. I know you wanted to be able to relate better to your fleet mates.
So, you're saying that when I'm not around all the fleet's Belles hurry to their radio rooms to talk about booze?
A drink made out of potatoes might sound silly, but it can certainly pack a punch.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, I did, and yes, I am. I'm extremely happy. I feel closer to everyone than I ever have before.
Do not worry, Kanchou. Rest assured that all personal talk is kept off the battlefield.
That's what I've heard. I may have to try some soon. Though, I hope I can keep myself from laughing when I do.
I can't thank you enough, Kanchou. I feel like I've finally found my place among the fleet.
Well, stick close to me, and I promise to do my best to make you always feel at home.
Oh, you're too kind, Kanchou...
*ALARM*
Here we go again. Think you can get the word out to everyone?
Certainly. It'll only take a moment to have the fleet prepared.
@BATTLE
What's wrong, Nenohi? You look more downtrodden than I'm used to seeing you.
Oh, Kanchou, it's nothing. Daijōbudesu.
Hey. I can tell that something is bothering you, even if you try to hide it.
...Fine, Kanchou, if you insist on knowing. It's my stamp collection. It's begun to stagnate.
Are your stamps deteriorating in some way? Or...
Gomen'nasai - I said that badly. I take very good care of my collection. I just haven't had the chance to add any new stamps to it for quite some time.

Fields.MenuText: Seriously? You're this depressed because of stamps?
Well, this just can't stand. How can I help?
I understand, I've collected things. It's always disheartening when your collection comes to a stop.

Fields.DialogueText: Sōda! Well... more accurately, a lack thereof. Is that idea really so preposterous?
I'm not sure, Kanchou. With the war on, fewer new stamps are being created, and there is little time to look for them.
My stamps haven't come to a stop! Don't even think that, Kanchou!
My collection is very important to me. They cheer me up and make me happy. Without the opportunity to add to it, I'm a little down.
My collection is one of the many reasons I hope for a speedy end to this war. Then I'll be able to visit new lands and learn more of their histories through tiny pictures.
I can't say that I've heard stamps described as a window into history before.
Oh, but they are. They immortalize the moments that mean the most to the country that issues them.
*ALARM*
Oh, right, that's what I came here to tell you. We're approaching some Morganas.
You should've started with that, Kanchou!
You were pouting. You can't blame me for getting distracted.
@BATTLE
Can you believe what Augusta said about Argonaut? I had no idea the ships of one nation could have such strong opinions about one another.
Hang on - let's find somewhere more private. I don't think the crew needs to hear Belle gossip.
Oh, I am sure it is fine, Kanchou. We're all friends, are we not?

Fields.MenuText: And how would you like it if your little "capsizing problem" was the talk of Augusta's crew, hmm?
There's a part of me that would love to see how this all plays out, but I know I couldn't stand the paperwork when it was done.
All I know is that if I were Augusta, I wouldn't want something I told you in confidence to make its way around the fleet.

Fields.DialogueText: I told you that in confidence, Kanchou! I'd be livid!
Oh. Wakarimashita.
That does make sense. I wouldn't want her to do the same to me...
You're right. I'm lucky to have a wise kanchou.
Oh, you're just trying to butter me up.
Not entirely!
I just know that gossip never leads to anything good. We don't want infighting among our fleet, do we? Loose lips sink ships.
That's what I'm talking about! What chilling words. "Loose lips sink ships..." Did you come up with that?
*ALARM*
You know what else sinks ships? Morganas.
Not if I have anything to say about it.
@BATTLE
Do you see where I'm going with this?
... Oh. Yes, now I see, Kanchou.
Kanchou?
Just... trust me. The navy rumor mill is a mighty and terrible weapon, and you can't control what it's going to hit once you load the ammo.
Gomen'nasai. I still don't understand the metaphor. Are you...
I'm just afraid that if some version of what you say gets back to Argonaut feelings will be hurt.
Kanchou, Kanchou, I would like you to see my decorations. I think they are very nice.
All right, let me take a look. I'm prepared to be amazed.
Wow... that's a lot of red and blue streamers.
It took a while, I'll admit.
You have quite the sense of decoration, don't you?
Aw, thanks, Kanchou.
What's the occasion, anyhow? Is it someone's birthday? I see you've made a cake.
I did and it is. It's the birthday of an American Belle, and I tried to make her an appropriate display. I even have coffee.
Hmmmm... I'm seeing one issue with this little plan of yours, Nenohi.
An issue? What kind of issue?

Fields.MenuText: Not enough cake.
What if one of the streamers catches fire from the birthday candles?
Did you get her a birthday present?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sure I prepared enough. If not, I'll simply forgo my own share. After all, it's her favorite, not mine.
I believe you're worrying too much, Kanchou. There aren't that many streamers.
Of course. I'm not telling you what it is, though. It's a secret, and I've learned my lesson on sharing secrets.
I am one hundred percent prepared, Kanchou. There's nothing you can say to make me think otherwise.
How about... she's a Belle. How are you planning on getting her this far away from her ship?
I take it you forgot about that little fact?
I didn't forget... there is simply more planning to be done.
Well, good luck with that. While you're planning, I'll go make sure no Morganas come by to ruin your beautiful, if somewhat wasted, decorations.
Hmmmm... maybe I can have this room redecorated aboard her ship. Or...
@BATTLE
Over four hundred!
I believe it. Oh - those stars hanging from ceiling are nice.
Go shinsetsu ni dōmo! Thank you!
This must have taken you some time.
I heard you wanted to see me, Nenohi. What's going on?
I need your help, Kanchou.
Well, that's what I'm here for. What's wrong?
Oh, nothing. I just need you to throw a surprise birthday party in my stead, that's all. Okay?
Is this about your friend you decorated the mess for again?
Yes, I, uh... I'm not sure I can have anyone aboard her ship do it without her finding out. I need someone I can trust. That's you. So please, Kanchou?

Fields.MenuText: I'm flattered, but I'm not sure I'm suited for the job.
You want me to take the time out of my day to throw a party?
How am I supposed to say no when you're pouting like that?

Fields.DialogueText: What do you mean? You're the most suited! Who am I supposed to trust more than my wonderful kanchou?
It won't take that long. I already did all the designing and planning. I just need you to execute it!
You're not supposed to say no. That's the point, Kanchou.
All right, all right, you've got me, Nenohi.
Really? You'll do it?! Anata wa saikou! Thank you, thank you, thank you!
*ALARM*
We can talk about how great I am later. Right now, we have company.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, you were amazing! She loved it, and she was surprised too!
I hope you're talking about your Belle friend. I don't think I've surprised anyone else lately.
Yes. Mochiron! Thank you so much for doing that for me. And from what she said, you followed my directions to the letter.

Fields.MenuText: Why mess with perfection?
Yeah, no. That was just 100% frantic improvisation. Sorry.
I did my best, but I'm pretty sure I messed a few things up.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I wouldn't say I'm perfect, but the party was pretty close, according to her.
Well, whatever you did was great. She had a wonderful time.
Well, she didn't notice. She said it was the best surprise she'd had in ages.
I really can't thank you enough, Kanchou. If there's ever anything I can do for you, please, just let me know.
I didn't do it to call in a favor. I just wanted to do something nice for you.
You're too sweet, Kanchou. You can't keep doing all this nice stuff for me when I'm not doing anything to deserve it.
You've been doing plenty, Nenohi. Just keep the fleet running as smoothly as you've been, and I'll do my best to help you however I can.
*ALARM*
Of course, you can also help me with these incoming Morganas.
You don't have to tell me twice, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
Nenohi, what's been going on with our radios lately? I keep getting reports of interference.
It's just a little static, Kanchou. It's not out of the ordinary.
I disagree. Static comes and goes, especially when you're moving all over the ocean. We've been getting steady interference for a while now.
Kanchou, have you been listening in on the fleet's communications? I thought that was my job.

Fields.MenuText: What, I can't take an interest in the things you like?
I'm not trying to step on your toes, Nenohi. I'm just adding my two cents.
I get reports. I'm the captain, it's what I do.

Fields.DialogueText: I didn't say that! But if you want to start sharing interests with me, perhaps we should start with something a little less complicated.
I appreciate it, Kanchou, but I have everything under control.
Really? Because it seems to me you're speaking from some experience.
All I'm saying is that this static seems unusual.
I'm assuming it's metal in the water. Signals bounce around, you know.
Hmmm... what would you say to falling back to the last place we had a clear signal? If it's still clear, then you're right - it's some common interference.
And if the static remains?
Then we might have something to worry about.
Hai. I understand, Kanchou. This is war. It pays to take precautions.
@BATTLE
You seem to be in a good mood, Nenohi. Have the radios improved?
But that won't stop me from enjoying the time I get to spend with my sisters in arms!
I've also started recruiting a number of different pen pals. Several crew members have promised to write me after we part ways.
That's one way to collect new stamps. I like the ingenuity.
I won't deny that thought crossed my mind - but I'm also eager to learn all about the rest of the world. There are even parts of Japan I'd like to know more about.
Plus the stamps.
Hai, hai! I can't wait for all the wonderful stamps to come to me! Are you happy, Kanchou?
When you're looking that happy, how could I not be?
Oh, shush, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: Just make sure you don't sink the ship under the weight of all those letters you'll receive.
I hope you realize you'll have to use stamps to send letters back to them.
How many pen pals have you actually collected?

Fields.DialogueText: I almost sink once and you never let me forget it.
Oh, don't worry about that, I only need one of each unique stamp. I have plenty of extras.
Well, it's a little embarrassing, but I'm rounding toward the triple digits.
*ALARM*
Morganas. It seems like we're running into more and more of them every day.
They're hardly a challenge for me, Kanchou. We have this under control.
@BATTLE
Gomen'nasai. I'm afraid they're as scratchy as ever.
Nenohi, how has the crew been faring? Have you been picking up on any signals?
Do you mean strange radio signals, Kanchou? Not particularly.
Sorry. I phrased that badly - I meant strange or troubling sentiments.
I can't say that I have. Although, now that you mention it, some of my regular off board conversationalists have made themselves scarce.
How odd. From what I'm hearing, other ships are dealing with mounting frustrations.
Yabai. That's the last thing we'd want.

Fields.MenuText: You're right. We should be fighting the Morganas, not ourselves.
Well, the last thing I'd want is to be dead at the bottom of the ocean. I'd say this is a close second, though.
I could just be overreacting. I have a tendency to worry too much sometimes.

Fields.DialogueText: We have enough threats without becoming one ourselves.
Well, I suppose you have a point. Though the argument could be made that one will lead to the other.
I don't think you worry too much, Kanchou. I trust your instincts.
Have you had any trouble with the crew at all?
Not particularly. They all seem as happy and absorbed in their duties as ever.
Well, if you wouldn't mind, I'd like you to keep an ear out for any dissent among the ships. I'm in need of your help.
It would be an honor, Kanchou. I'm glad to be here for you to lean on in times of need.
Well, I'm done being needy for the moment, but thank you. Now, let's keep an eye on the horizon for any threats.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, we've returned to the last location where we had a clear signal.
How's the interference?
The static is still present. I think you were onto something.

Fields.MenuText: That's not what I wanted to hear.
Of course. I'm always right.
You're not telling me what you think I want to hear, are you?

Fields.DialogueText: Look at the bright side, Kanchou. You were right.
I'm not sure about always, but you were certainly right this time.
Don't worry. I always make sure to tell you the truth, Kanchou.
What should we do now? What's our next move?
We should make port. I don't want to stay on the seas for too long while we don't know what's going on with this interference.
I... may have a location in mind, if it's not too much trouble. A port town in Sumatra.
Huh. Well, it's as convenient as anywhere else. Why, though?
Well... I wasn't going to bring it up, but I have heard about some rare stamps among the shops in the port.
Heh. Well, I suppose it's your lucky day. Alert the rest of the fleet. We're making our way south.
Yatta! You're too good to me, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
Nenohi, are you okay? Shouldn't you be excited to get to port? Your stamps are closer than ever, after all.
I am excited. It's just... we've received some transmissions from Japan.
Really? It's been quite some time since you got word from your home. I'd expect you to be a little homesick by now.
My government is full of old men who have never seen a day of hard work in their lives, sending young men to go out and die.
And they do it on the premise that the Japanese are better than all others. I have seen others. I have made friends among many people.
I knew Japanese government officials were fools before, but now? Now I think they will lead us to ruin.

Fields.MenuText: If it makes you feel any better, you'll always have a family with the fleet.
That's a shame, Nenohi. I hope I never disappoint you the same way.
Give it time. They could still learn the error of their ways.

Fields.DialogueText: I feel at home here. More than I did in a nation I disagree with so frequently.
Oh, you won't, Kanchou. I don't believe I've ever been disappointed in you.
I do not believe they are good men, Kanchou. Bad men rarely change.
I wish I could make them change, make them see the world the way I see it.
Don't worry about making them change. You are strong, independent, and wise beyond your years. Don't let them hold that much power over you.
Dōmo arigatōgozaimasu. It means a lot to hear you say that.
@BATTLE
They're... well, they're far from comforting.
There you are, Nenohi. Did you get all the stamps you were hoping for?
Unfortunately, the bounty of stamps was exaggerated.
So not even one new stamp? That's a shame.
Well, not quite. The crew did find me one or two new stamps I'd never seen before. Look at this one. Isn't it hypnotizing?

Fields.MenuText: Oh, yes. I could see myself spending a whole day staring at that.
It's very well made, but it's just a stamp to me, Nenohi.
I can't quite tell what it's supposed to be. Is that a... dog?

Fields.DialogueText: Sōda ne! It truly encompasses what's important to the nation. All in one tiny portrait. Truly fantastic!
Kanchou, it may be a simple stamp, but it's so much more than that at the same time.
A dog? I think we may need to get your eyes checked. It doesn't look anything like a dog.
I know you've been busy with your stamp hunt, but I was wondering whether you'd had the chance to investigate the radios further.
I'm afraid I haven't made much progress, Kanchou. Mōshiwake arimasendeshita. I'll get right on it.
It's all right, Nenohi. I feel a little safer now that we're in port. I just want to make sure I'm not feeling a false sense of security.
*ALARM*
Well, we're not as secure as we might like.
We can handle a few Morganas. I fear there's something worse over the horizon.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, I have news, and it's not good.
The static. I know.
It's not only that. From what I've heard, our port has been experiencing the same thing. Strange radio signals that have been playing on multiple frequencies.
Is this some kind of jamming network? Are they trying to interrupt our communications?
I don't think it's that simple. Apparently, these radio signals aren't always just white noise. Sometimes they're talking, telling stories or something. Stories that have set the town against itself.
According to the crew, walking through the streets is like walking across no man's land. They're worried that the slightest misstep could set all the townspeople off.

Fields.MenuText: So the town's a powder keg because of these stories? Not your average radio plays, then.
Stories? What's going on here? And who is responsible?
It sounds like you're being a little dramatic. They're just stories, after all.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure - I haven't actually heard them myself. Though I'd assume not.
At least we're one step closer to finding the answers for those questions.
You may be surprised how many battles have been started because of a story or two.
I need to look into this more, but right now I'm worried our radios are going to start causing us more harm than they're worth.
I think you're right. We should tell everyone to silence their radios unless it's an emergency.
Already done. All communications are going through me.
What? When did you do this?
A while ago, Kanchou. I trusted your instincts that something was wrong about the static.
That would explain the lack of reports I've received today.
And also why our ship is in better shape than this town.
You have good instincts too, Nenohi.
I was just following your lead. Like I said, I trust you.
@BATTLE
... You're a hard person to compliment.
Nenohi, what's going on? I was told it was an emergency.
Hai. Kanchou, I found the broadcast.
Really? What's it saying?
I don't want to play it too loud. I'd rather the crew not be influenced by these words. Lean in and listen.
... In The Hundred Years' War, the French and English fought each other with merciless and treacherous tactics...
So it's a history lesson? That's what we're so afraid of?
There are others in French, Russian, English, Chinese...more languages than I can count. All tell of various wars, massacres and atrocities committed against the speakers of that language.

Fields.MenuText: So it is just a history lesson.
Can we block the signals?
Do we know who's broadcasting?

Fields.DialogueText: In a sense, but it's also much more than that.
Aside from eliminating radio communication, there's not much else to do.
Someone who knows many languages. Other than that, no.
These stories could bring up a lot of forgotten history and affect countless members of the fleet. Our strength lies in our differences, but there's also weakness there.
Sometimes it's easier to forget the past than forgive it. I get that.
I have to thank you again for limiting radio communication to emergencies only. I have a feeling we'd be in hot water if you hadn't.
I miss talking to my friends every day over the radio, but I have been receiving more letters than usual, so there's a silver lining.
*ALARM*
And there's the dark cloud. It's time for that emergency use of the radio. Let's get everyone ready for a fight.
@BATTLE
Enemy incoming!
@BATTLE
Kanchou, I think I figured something out during that last battle.
What do you mean? Are you talking about the broadcasts?
Hai. The stories started appearing on more frequencies just before the Morganas struck. It was always likely there was a connection, but I think the evidence is now compelling.

Fields.MenuText: So the Morganas are supporting human fifth columnists?
You think the Morganas are the cause of the broadcasts?
Hm. Maybe the Morganas are getting into show business, and they're starting by producing radio programs.

Fields.DialogueText: I'd rather believe that there's no human involvement at all.
That would be a scary thought indeed.
Not my first thought, but now I hope that's it. I'd like some entertainment on the high seas.
If I'm right, and the Morganas are somehow broadcasting these stories during battle to try and distract us, then that means they're even more sinister than we know.
I think the radio broadcasts are well within their powers. It's the knowledge of history that surprises me.
I have an idea, but we're going to have to engage more Morganas.
Slow down there, Nenohi. Let's restock first, then head back out for the hunt.
I can keep going, Kanchou! I hardly got close to sinking in that last battle.
As impressive as that is, let's play it safe. No need to take unnecessary risks.
Haaaiiiiii.  But it's hardly a risk.
Ī shitekidesu. It didn't make much sense to me either at first... but they do occasionally take prisoners.
Yeah.
Morganas, dead ahead!
@BATTLE
Kanchou, is everything okay in port? I haven't been able to get so much as a smile on the crew's face since we docked.

Fields.MenuText: Everything's fine, Nenohi. Don't worry about it.
It's not good. It's worse than we left it.
It's hard to explain. You might want to see for yourself.

Fields.DialogueText: Too late. I'm already worried about it.
Worse? How much worse?
I would if I could. Unfortunately, I can't leave the ship.
Kanchou, just tell me what's going on.
Words were said, threats were made, and a few people got hurt. It's not pretty out there, Nenohi.
How bad could it be? She's only telling war stories after all, isn't she?
In a way. Just... more personalized for the townsfolk. From what I've heard, she's spreading stories about family feuds and betrayals and dredging up the past.
We need to put a stop to this.
Yeah, but how? Send the crew to run through the town and destroy every radio? That's just going to start a riot.
Sōda ne. We need to find the source of these broadcasts and put a stop to them.
If anyone can do it, it's you.

We've done some discreet asking around - fishermen have gone missing over the last few weeks. I guess she has ways of making them talk about everyday life back home. It might not even require torture.
Kanchou, I've found something. I'm positive that a Funayūrei's responsible now.
Why are you so sure?
She signed off, like a true radio host. I believe she must be getting cocky.

Fields.MenuText: This is excellent, Nenohi. We're one step closer to putting a stop to her.
Let's not follow her lead. We can't get ahead of ourselves.
Are we sure it's not a mislead, or a trap?

Fields.DialogueText: It may only be one step, but that's how every sprint starts, right?
Hai. You're right, I know it - but I feel like she's so close now. I can almost taste her defeat.
Maybe. Honestly, I'm not even sure if she knows we're on to her.
So which one is it?
It's Mistrust. A fitting name, don't you think?
A little on the nose, but it certainly fits.
*ALARM*
Morganas. Probably expecting us to be at odds with each other after Mistrust's last broadcast.
Let's show them how wrong they are.
@BATTLE
There you are, Nenohi.  How goes pinpointing the transmission location?
Gomen'nasai. Not well, Kanchou. The signal strength is barely enough to be audible.
You think one of those Morganas is Mistrust?

Fields.MenuText: We can hope so.
You don't think that'd be too easy?
No. We'll know her when we see her.

Fields.DialogueText: As long as we maintain hope, we can overcome anything she throws at us.
Probably, but why can't things be easy every now and then?
You're probably right, but a girl can hope, can't she?
You know, there's only one way to find out if Mistrust is over there.
I was thinking the exact same thing, Kanchou.
*BOOM*
We're taking shots? The Morganas aren't close enough yet.
No, those came from behind us. Look.
Those are civilian vessels.
I recognize them. They were docked with us in port.
You know every ship we've docked next to?
When you can't leave your ship, you spend a lot of time looking from your deck longingly.
Why are they attacking us?
*BOOM*
No time to ask. We need to get out of their range and deal with those Morganas on the horizon, whether or not Mistrust is among them.
@BATTLE
Kanchou... I know why the civilian ships attacked us.
Judging by that expression, can I assume it wasn't a simple misunderstanding?
I'm sorry to say that it was not. Based on wreckage we've found, we've pieced together that the crews turned on each other. They killed their own friends, Kanchou.
Mistrust?
I assume so. She must've gotten them to attack themselves, and... maybe she told them to attack us next.

Fields.MenuText: She must see us as a threat, then.
I miss the days of pirates being the biggest threat on the ocean.
She's scarier than I thought she was.

Fields.DialogueText: Hai. If only we could find her. I'd show her how much of a threat I can be.
The idea that a Funayūrei can mess with your head so much that you turn on your fellow man is not to your liking? I understand.
You wouldn't chicken out on me now, would you, Kanchou? You're braver than that.
Mistrust is going to be sorry she ever crossed our path. You can count on that, Nenohi.
I count on everything you say, Kanchou.
*ALARM*
Great. I guess we took too long to look through what was left of those ships, huh?
Gomen'nasai. I'm sorry, Kanchou. I'm the one who wanted to stay and look for answers.
Don't be sorry. We found our answers, now let's earn them.
@BATTLE
Morganas sighted off the starboard bow!
@BATTLE
Ah, Nenohi, there you are.  How are you holding up after that last battle?
Watashi wa genki desu. I'm fine, but...
Kanchou, what's going on? Did I hear gunfire just now?

Fields.MenuText: Yeah. We're doing what we can, but...
Maybe. I didn't hear anything.
Better gunfire than explosions.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, no... What's going on in town?
Kanchou, look at me. What happened in town?
Explosions!? Explain.
There was a situation on the dock, but it's been handled for now.
Go on.
There was a man. He'd gone red with rage. He had a gun.
He killed someone?
We stepped in before it could come to that. It was just a flesh wound - the intended victim'll be all right.
We need to do something. We can't leave the townspeople to go crazy listening to Mistrust's broadcasts. What if they turn on each other like those ships that attacked us?
What do you suggest we do? I can't think of any solution that wouldn't cause a riot anyway.
I have an idea... I just hope it'll work.
The actual victim, I suppose. The intended corpse.
Are we good to initiate the plan?
We're ready to broadcast on as many frequencies as we can. Are you ready on your end, Nenohi?
Honestly? I'm a little nervous, but the good kind of nervous.

Fields.MenuText: I know it might not do much to assuage your fears since it's a radio - but you look fantastic, Nenohi.
Do you really think this will work?
Let's make this quick. This is the kind of thing that Morganas love to interrupt.

Fields.DialogueText: You're so kind, Kanchou.
Oh, it'll work. I know it will. If my time with the fleet has taught me anything, it's what brings people together.
You're not wrong about that. They just love to pop in when they're unwanted. But not even Morganas can stop me now.
Attention, fair townspeople. You may not know me - I'm sadly unable to truly enjoy your fair home - but you must listen to me.
I know you're scared. I know you have threats on all sides, and now it feels like you can't trust your neighbors. But now is not the time for distrust. Now is the time for bravery.
You have all been tricked by one of the enemies you so fear. A monster of the sea, Mistrust, has been whispering in your ears and convincing you to hate each other, all for her own ends.
You're letting her win. Do not let her take your home away from you. Come together and show her that you will not be her pawns.
Our fleet is here to stop her, but to do that, we have to know that you're safe from her poisonous words. We need you all to make a move against her today so we can destroy her tomorrow.
Everyone, take your radios, whatever you're using to listen to this broadcast, and turn them off.
Fight for your home. Fight for your friends. Don't destroy yourselves, destroy the transmission!
... Do you think it worked?
Look! People are running from their homes... to throw their radios into the sea!
Overkill, but effective.
Hai.
You did it, Nenohi. Now that you've protected them from themselves, let's go protect them from Mistrust.
@BATTLE
I'm amazed by what you've done, Nenohi. I've received reports that say the town has already started to improve.
Without Mistrust riling them on, they're becoming a functioning community again.
I didn't do all that much. I just reminded them who the real enemy was.
Wait until they hear about this back home. Maybe those stuffy old government types will start listening to you.
I won't be too bothered if they don't. Japan doesn't feel much like home to me. It hasn't for some time.

Fields.MenuText: Well, you've always got the fleet.
In a good way or a bad way?
You know, they say "Home is where the heart is."

Fields.DialogueText: Hai. I can honestly say that my family is this fleet. Orders or not, I will protect my family.
A little of both, honestly. I don't know. I suppose we'll find out in time.
Well, that would make sense. My heart hasn't been with Japan for quite a while.
Oh, Kanchou, I meant to tell you earlier, but I have good news.
You know I'm always eager to hear some of that.
It seems Mistrust was listening to my little speech. She sent out a monologue of her own.
I take it you caught it on one of her frequencies.
It was on all the frequencies. She obviously wasn't thinking clearly. Her signal was so strong that I tracked her location halfway through her little tirade.
So we know where to find her?
In a word - hai.
@BATTLE
We're approaching the place where the signal is coming from.
So that's her?
That's Mistrust all right. I can smell the evil from here.

Fields.MenuText: Should we be wearing earplugs?
Doesn't look all that scary. I've picked more horrifying things out of my teeth.
You think she's surprised? I hope she's surprised.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't think we have to worry about her poisonous words. She'll be too busy taking fire to talk.
If that's true, then I simply must ask what you've been eating, sir.
I hope she was expecting us. I hope she thinks she's stronger than us. It'll make the win that much better.
Before we get to fighting, do you have any taunts or choice words to call out over the radio? Now's your chance.
Shinpaishinaide kudasai. I've prepared a short but sweet speech for her. She'll be receiving it shortly.
Receiving it? Did you mail it to her?
Actually, I wrote it on my torpedos.
Have I told you lately I love your style?
And I love your compliments. But right now, I just want to see how much she likes my style.
@BATTLE
Would it be too cliche to say I eat Morganas for breakfast?
That settles it. You're going to have to start eating better from now on.
Kanchou, we did it! Mistrust is fleeing!

Fields.MenuText: For now.
The battle isn't over yet, Nenohi. We've still got a bunch of her friends surrounding us.
I knew you could do it, Nenohi.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't rain on my parade, Kanchou! This has to count as a victory.
After Mistrust, I don't think we'll have much of a problem against these grunts.
Thank you, Kanchou. I rely on your faith more than you know.
The power of unity has conquered Mistrust. We are definitely throwing a party tonight! I can't wait to get on the radio and talk to all of my friends again!
I didn't realize how much I missed having late night conversations with the other Belles!
*BOOM*
Nenohi! A little focus, please?
Gomen. I got a little excited. The radio talk will have to wait until later.
Actually, get on the radio.
Eh?
Get the fleet communicating openly again. Let's get everyone back in perfect sync.
Sugoi! That's a wonderful idea, Kanchou. We won't have anything to worry about with everyone communicating with each other.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, look at my room! There are so many letters, you can't even see the floor.
I'm glad to see you got your package. I was interested to see the contents of such a large shipment.
They're letters from the town, Kanchou. I haven't read them all, but from what I've read, they're thank you notes. One letter said they owed their life to me.
They're probably right. You saved that town, Nenohi. Hell, if it wasn't for you, our crew might've been in dire straits as well. You've been amazing.
No, not just me. I was just following your lead. I'd be nothing without you, Kanchou.
That's just not true. I'm pretty sure you'd be fine on your own.
Well, I don't want to find out.
Come here, Kanchou.
Oh, a hug? What's this for?
It's a thank you. For being as amazing as you are.

Fields.MenuText: Well, you're welcome.
What makes me so great?
I thought we decided you were the amazing one.

Fields.DialogueText: And so modest too, heh.
Everything. Everything makes you great.
What? We can't both be amazing? There's no rule against that, is there?
About this giant mess of letters... I'm not sure I'm going to be able to look through all of these on my own. Think you have some time to help me with that?
I always have time for you. I just hope you don't mind me adding one more letter to the pile.
Is this... a letter from you?
Yeah, sorry about the lack of a stamp. I couldn't find any I thought fitting for you.
Kanchou... you're better than any stamp.
*ALARM*
Think we can pick up this conversation later?
Hai. I wouldn't have it any other way.
